title: 110_hr2610
content: The "Skill Game Protection Act" is the short title of this Act, as stated in Section 1. Congressional findings are outlined in Section 2. The Congress finds that millions of Americans enjoy competing in skill-based games like bridge, mahjong, backgammon, and poker online for income, where success is based on skill rather than chance, distinguishing them from traditional gambling games. The Federal Government should ensure that skill games prevent minors from playing for money, identify and refer persons with compulsive behavior to treatment, and prevent operators from participating in criminal or terrorist money laundering. The Federal Government should ensure that skill games prevent minors from playing for money, refer persons with compulsive behavior to treatment, and prevent operators from participating in criminal or terrorist money laundering. Additionally, appropriate taxes should be collected. Section 1084 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to clarify that the term 'bets or wagers' excludes skill-based games like poker, chess, bridge, and mahjong. Operators must comply with regulations to ensure fair competition among participants. The Skill Game Protection Act amends Subchapter IV of chapter 53 of title 31, requiring operators of online skill games to implement safeguards for age verification and location restrictions within 180 days. Taxes must also be accounted for. The Skill Game Protection Act mandates operators of online skill games to implement safeguards for taxes, fraud prevention, compulsive participation, and privacy protection. Chapter 53 of Title 31, United States Code, is amended to include a new item after section 5367. SEC. 5. RULES OF CONSTRUCTION. Section 5362(1)(E) of title 31, United States Code is amended to exclude participation in activities that do not constitute "bets or wagers" and are compliant with regulations. The Act clarifies that section 1084 of title 18, United States Code does not apply to non-sports wagering.
